question.title: Does your business have a probation policy in place for new employees?
How long is a typical probationary period for new employees at your business?
Does your business currently employ anyone on any of the following contracts?

options.label: Agency contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker who has been supplied by a temporary work agency to work under the supervision and direction of a hirer.

options.label: Casual contract
options.description: This refers to an agreement with a worker without a formal contract of employment.

options.label: Fixed term contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which is set out and agreed to last for up to 12 months.

options.label: Minimum hours contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which guarantees them between 1 and 20 hours of work per week, but where they are regularly offered more hours, with the exact hours of work to be determined in accordance with business need.

options.label: Seasonal contract
options.description: This refers to a temporary contract of employment with a worker, which is used to cover temporary seasonal demand, such as for Christmas or summer.

options.label: Variable hours contract
options.description: This refers to an agreement with a fixed hourly rate of pay but without a guaranteed fixed number of hours per week. Alternatively, this also refers to an agreement with a fixed minimum number of hours per week but the worker is regularly offered hours of work beyond contractual obligations in accordance with business need.

options.label: Zero hours contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which clarifies that they may be asked to perform work, but there is no set minimum number of hours.

question.title: Has your business gone through a collective redundancy consultation in the last 12 months?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’collective redundancy consultation’

contents.description: This refers to a process that must be followed if an employer is making 20 or more employees redundant within a 90-day period at a single establishment. These consultations should be carried out with a view of reaching an agreement on the proposed redundancies, although they do not need to end in agreement.
This includes options to avoid redundancies, reduce the number of employees to be made redundant, and mitigate the consequences of any dismissals.
